comment.body: Make sure you sign the zite.

@Krixano: You can get to this by dragging the button at the top right to the left and scrolling all the way down. First click Sign, then Publish. Not sure if this is your problem or not but people have forgotten to sign in the past.
@Zerov: You might need to open port 15441.
@Zerov: What do you mean by you don't have a public IP?
@Krixano: Your router should have a public IP afaik.
http://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#do-i-need-to-have-a-port-opened (clearnet)
The only thing I can think of is port forwarding the 15441 port on your router.

Although I don't know if it would error out if you didn't sign *both* content.json files, because it looks like you have two. Sorry if you already did that too, I'm just trying to go through things that could be wrong.
@Zerov: No problem. The only two things I can think of right now is either the port or not signing the `data/users/content.json` file also.
@Zerov: I got the content.json file to download when I visited your zite - unlike before where it would fail to download. Now it's just stuck on a blank screen trying to load.
@Reke: I am also getting this issue.
I got a similar email from the same person: http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu/1501083148
@Glightstar: That's what I was thinking too.
@Peeper: I think he's just answering questions mostly right now.

@Jayofthezero: *I believe* you can do desktop (not push) notifications without a Service Worker *with the restriction that the tab remains open* (in firefox at least). I think I told Glightstar: about this quite a while ago. People can start using this until we have some way to do push notifications (can't the client handle this by having zites register with the client just like how the new feed works?). https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/notification
link appears to be invalid. I'm wondering if there is a bug with the shortener zite, because you other link was invalid also.
@Styromaniac: This shortened link and the other one you posted say they are invalid for me. But other ones that I have clicked have not said that.
Thanks!

btw, the bug with the signing is fixed now. Before, Git Center was using your zeroid to sign your merger zite when you clicked the publish button, which is why you had to go to the merger zite and sign that way, so it uses your private key instead. However, Ivanq has fixed this with the latest update so that the blue sign and publish button always uses your private key now.
He isn't able to sign and publish it because last time he told me he isn't near the computer that has it (or something like that).
you can just do `git remote add name address/location`. Then do a force git push `git push name -f`. This is what I did with gitcenter.
No, I don't have problems uploading images. I don't get any prompt. However, if it's a new thing - I haven't updated Firefox Nightly in a few days. I'll test it out later, after updating.

@Binchan: You should be able to using the `comment and close` button on the issue page. I just did it on an issue on ZeroMedium repo and it worked for me. @Git Center: I have another request. Currently the only way to see if an issue is closed or not on the issue page is by noticing the color of the dot, which can sometimes be hard to distinguish quickly (especially for color blind people). It would not only help to determine if the issue is closed or not but also clean up the interface a little if you created separate sub-tabs for open and closed issues (and, if you want, a tab for all issues maybe) - or at least some type of filtering/organization.

@Binchan: Ah - yeah, wouldn't have got that because I was closing my own issue. That is helpful to know. @Git Center: I agree, I think the repo owner should be able to close and comment. I also think that the repo owner should be able to reopen issues too.
@Glightstar: I'm not sure why it's not working. The method he described is what I did for all of my repos (aside from having to recreate the bare git repo).

@Git Center: I was able to download the repo. The stuff in the log tab doesn't show up (continually says "Loading latest info", however, on the code tab, I can see the latest commit and the branch and all the files.
@Glightstar: Okay, now I can see some of the commits in the log tab. It's because it hasn't finished downloading I believe.
@Glightstar: Make sure you refresh, If you haven't already (which you probably have, but I'm just making sure).
@Glightstar: That should have popped up before it even shows your page, and thus before it redirects. That's what it did for me.

@Git Center: Because your not able to connect to any of the peers. That's something that I don't always understand with ZeroNet, but it happens quite a bit when a zite has low peer count. I think you just need to wait till more peers download the repo. I would have suggested to use bigcat.tk, however bigcat doesn't allow you to increase a zite's size limit yourself.
@Glightstar: @Git Center: I'm very unsure that that would help because even if you have the content.json file, you still need to be able to download the rest of the files.
@Glightstar: @Git Center: After waiting for the whole repo to download, I don't see anything anymore. This appeared to happen when the other branch showed up.
@Glightstar: @Git Center: Is it perhaps because the repo is so big and it just takes forever to load?

@Glightstar: @Git Center: I'm getting this error in the terminal:
```
Uncaught (in promise) File doesn't exist: merged-GitCenter/1EjXEyudstY8dN3F8V5od9KoS1bkAerz9x/thunderwave.git/objects/pack/pack-5796e45d59ffed6e3b1b89b6790e1c275b2f64fd.pack
```

It should also be noted that ZeroNet shows this as a missing file: `data/users/1CvyxRucf7BbDvGtFe5LayTS2qX88VN7Er/data.json`

@Glightstar: Yep, it's working for me now. @Git Center: It looks like there's a very small bug where if the branch name is too long to fit in just one line, it will overlap the next branch name listed.
@Glightstar: What the heck did you do? I'm wondering, how does removing a directory make all the commit-id's invalid?
@Glightstar: The data/users.json file never gets seeded, it has your private keys in there.
@Glightstar: Maybe he could have, but I've never know a `users.json` to be stored in a zite's data directory, but I'm not sure.
Yep, just released the new update. Haven't had a chance to create a post about it yet.
What do you mean?
@Binchan: I just realized that. What really confused me in the first place was that they seemed to have some of the same posts at first glance.

@BTC-E: I know what nofish's id is. noftsh looks very similar to nofish at first glance, so I think you can see my confusion. I'm not sure why your saying "please" when what I think/believe has no affect on you.
Sometimes this happens without realizing it because of library stuff.

I wouldn't recommend doing this because then the person would have to wait even longer to publish the message they just typed (20 seconds I think). I already get annoying after publishing something and waiting 20 seconds to publish another thing. *This would either double the time or if the person enters the message before the time is up to publish the change that tells others their typing, wouldn't tell others their typing because it will switch back right when they press enter (which means others won't know when someone's typing, making it useless in this case).*
The only other way is a centralized solution where you talk to a server on the clearnet.
@Git Center: It's *very* out of date. The person isn't managing it anymore, meaning we can't request things be added. And finally, it only has like 3 things on it, none of which I personally use.
@Git Center: For me, personally, I think white inputs would look too jarring. Perhaps they *could* be better with a lighter black/grey (but not a very light grey).
Apparently New York along with 16 other states are suing the FCC because of this (including the state where I live, Iowa).

You can turn off Firefox Shield in the options menu under `Nightly Data Collection and Use`. Also:
> There will be occasions where we might prompt you for participation first. This will happen when a particular study needs to collect data that is not covered by default data collection policy.  In these situations you'll see a complete disclosure of the data being collected in the study before you make the decision to participate.

[https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/lookingglass](https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/lookingglass)
> No changes will be made to Firefox unless you have opted in to this Alternate Reality Game.
@Binchan: I'm guessing you didn't see my my edit where I removed the stabe vs. nightly thing.
@Binchan: I think people exaggerate and blow things way out of proportion quite a lot, especially with browser and Operating System companies (Microsoft, Google, Mozilla).

@Binchan: And now you're basically saying that people are making all of this fuss because something *looks* like something it's not? And you're blaming Mozilla for that instead of the users who made these stupid assumptions? It's quite ridiculous in my view.

@Binchan: How about instead of focusing on all this petty crap, we start focusing on how terribly slow everything is? How about we start actually progressing and doing stuff rather than just complaining. Don't like current browsers, make a freaking new one instead of just complaining about it. That's just my point of view.
@Binchan: It's fine. I just hope people get my point that there are more important things to worry about than something like this.
